author: Peggy Fitzhugh Johnstone
description:
George Eliot has been widely praised both for the richness of her prose
and the universality of her themes. In this compelling study, Peggy
Fitzhugh Johnstone goes beyond these traditional foci to examine the role
of aggression in Eliot's fiction and to find its source in the author's
unconscious sense of loss stemming from traumatic family separations and
deaths during her childhood and adolescence. Johnstone demonstrates that
Eliot's creative work was a constructive response to her sense of loss
and that the repeating patterns in her novels reflect the process of
release from her state of mourning for lost loved ones.
